handNotes.handNote: Red crayon or thick red pencil. A different from Mitford's, that marks many of her letters, sometimes drawing diagonal lines across pages, and sometimes writing words overtop and perpendicularly across Mitford's writing. This hand has drawn a diagonal line in red pencil down page 3 of the manuscript of this letter.

Someone, apparently other than Mitford, perhaps cataloging letters and describing them. Page 2 of this letter manuscript bears horizontal cross-outs at lines 1 and 24 of paragraph 2, and a vertical line running down the center of the page. The hand has cross-written above the vertical line: "Omit all this it is told in the next letter." Page 3 of the manuscript bears horiontal cross-outs at lines 10 and 26, and a vertical line runs down the center of the page. The hand has cross-written above the vertical line:"Omit all this it is in the next letter."

div.p: I have been waiting till Easter should bring home Parliament then into the Country to thank you for your delightful account of your Glasgow excursion--oh what an honour & a pleasure it is to be selected as a friend to whom you like “to unburthen your thoughts”--& how heartily I sympatised with all your feelings whether stern or relenting--I had been waiting for a frank to tell you this--but I suppose indignation is a stonger impulse than pleasure for since I received the Examiner this morning I can no longer refrain from writing. I had read the article in the magazine wondering who could be meant--thinking how likely it was I he misrepresented but never for an instant dreaming that it could be aimed at you--of all impossible slanders that seemed the most impossible--& I am even now lost in astonishment at such a malicious falsehood finding a place in so respectable a publication. I suppose that as there is now no regular Editor the venom slid in undetected. I am almost glad that it did since it has afforded you an opportunity of making a defence & dignified & so spirited--What a necessary thing it is that a great painter should be a good writer! And really in these days when the appetite for anecdote as it is called (that is for scandal) is so craving & the gossip of a set of widowed women over a country tea table wielded in malice to the slander of literary chit chat, every man should be brought to illegible the illegible as a weapon of defence against his enemies his rivals & his friends. Do you know to which class the present author belongs?--I will not talk of him any more for it puts me in a passion_____ What became of your Glasgow culprit? Did he come back to London according to your behest? And is he likely to turn honest & make his way in the world? I think if any thing could reform a man your severity of words & kindnesses of wisdom would do so.

I believe you know my friend Mrs Hofland I have finished a letter from Miss Gower containing so remarkable an anecdote respecting her that I am tempted to transcribe it--to understand it I must tell you that Mrs Hofland has been for several years involved in a harassing suit on the illegible of which they had placed great reliance. And illegible have lost them. What a miserable thing is a illegibleChancery> suit. Now for Miss Gower's letter. The Hofland suit is decided in their favour--but all the costs being to be paid out of the property not on expence Mrs. Hof. says will come to them. Their lawyer had neglected to write & the news of the decision was brought by a neighbour who told her only that it was decided in their favour--she went to town to enquire was quite overcome by the information she received--I was about to mount the outside of the Twickenham coach to return all illegible as you may suppose when recollecting she should have sixpence in going by the Richmond stage & such an one being on hand, she withdrew her illegible although a most respectable woman with her husband at her side affected to make room for her--Home she came by the Richmond coach & saved her sixpence & her life. The Twickenham coach was overturned an hour after & that decent woman in whose place she would have sat killed on the spot. The husband had his collar bone & a rib broken. This most striking event gave a new & fast turn to her thoughts--I am sure you will feel as thankful as I do at the detail which she gave. in her most pathetic manner." _____ Having begun story telling I cannot tell you anotherone story which comes from Germany. The King of Naples having arrived at Longback was desirous to have the amusement of bear hunting which of course was to be provided for him but there being no bears illegible in the neighbourhood one was purchased of a Savoyard & placed a few miles out of town in a illegible. The King exulted at the story went by a train of illegible courtiers arrived near the place & the bear finding himself in the neighbourhood of the illegible good company fancied he was to perform as usual came on his hind legs in a most graceful attitude--which alas! had an effect on the hard heart of his Neopolitan majesty who discharged his piece & shot him dead. This story is none of my radical inventions--it came from Lord illegible to Mr. W.Elford & from him to me. ____

I have a great grievance just now which I have nothing to do with, but which I cannot help thinking a grievance nevertheless. The Duke of Wellington's sons are at home for the Eton They come every day to a little alehouse next door to learn French of a Jew who is lodging there for the purpose of teaching them. The poor little lads illegible, says my friend the landlord, are kept very strict. They never look up but their tutor corrects them, & there they sit in my parlour from eleven to half past four & never have a glass of anything. Without sympathising very deeply in the misfortune which my friend the alehouse keeper with a true illegible feeling considers as worth of ale. I am quite indignant at the poor little boys being cheated of their holidays. Is it not abominable? A worse iniquity than beating Napoleon. When they ought to be playing cricket or stealing illegible or doing mischief or doing nothing. The Battle of Waterloo was a illegible to this wickedness. The only thing that even looks like the holidays is their mode of conveyance which is generally illegible in a gig rain or shine.

illegible did you get a little letter which I sent to you at Glasgow. It is not worth asking for.--My father & mother join in kindest remembrances & I am ever
My dear Mr. Haydon
Most sincerely and affectionately yours
MM Mitford Were you not very affected at the death of poor John Keats? There is another proof of the terrible personality of the age. If he had lived I think his name would have been second only to Wordsworth's amongst the poets of the day--Indeed even now there are parts of Endymion which illegible no other man could have written.

B.R. Hayden, Esqre
St. John's Place
Lisson Grove North
Regent's Park
London

I am happy to tell you that after a great deal of enquiry & some threats we have succeeded in regaining your unintelligible puppy & have placed him in very good summer quarters. He is the largest young dog I ever saw in my life & gives promise of great strength--Once more farewell.
